The real skittles are made like jellybeans or M&Ms the center is pressed in a mold then it's put in a tumbler. It's like a small cement mixer without paddles inside. I think it's called panning. They are misted with water as they tumble, then it's like confectionery sugar gradually built up, then color is added, spinning constantly. Then they put a bit of wax to polish and prevent stickiness. I'm surprised Clair didn't try to watch a video of their manufactur. They make the stars for fireworks the same way, built up around a rice hull.  Oh and jawbreaker/godstoppers are built up like that too.

You're missing classic candy making tools, like a taffy hook and roller. A hook makes pulling easier than using two hands. A roller with divots gets you a sheet of candy with balls on it. One thing I can tell you is that these American versions have lots of preservatives and stuff that's not used over here in Europe. Hydrogenated fats are banned pretty much as manufacturers try to use healthier stuff. I've also seen that TBHQ a lot in your American candies, which is something no one puts in stuff here as it can be carcinogenic and kill in high concentrations...  Example - Skittles ingredients here in the UK: Sugar,Â Glucose Syrup,Â Palm Fat,Â Acids Citric Acid, Malic Acid,Â Dextrin,Â Maltodextrin,Â Flavourings,Â Colours E162, E171, E100, E160a, E132, E133, E163, E160e,Â Modified Starch,Â Acidity Regulator Trisodium Citrate,Â Glazing Agent Carnauba Wax.

I must say, it does feel rather peculiar to comment upon this series regarding something that - when I first discovered your channel and this series - I skipped past/over. And although it may not be the most exciting nor most entertaining part of these videos, it is most helpful.   This bit, of course, being at the end - whereby Claire goes over her final collection of instructions, to form her 'gourmet' method.    I very much appreciate the way in which this segment is phrased. For the non-professional chefs, that is. Claire makes it clear in which 'category' each 'group' of steps within the method are.     e.g. "To temper the chocolate: do x, y and z".    Quite a small detail, but one much appreciated by those who need it. Moi.

Great job and great work for working on your own candies! I have learned to appreciate skittles more; and the hard work you placed into making the recipe, has made me better appreciate the kind gift of the recipe that you made at the end of the show! Wow that's actually very interesting... American skittles has different flavours to the UK ones! In America you have it as Red: Strawberry Orange: Orange Yellow: Lemon Green: Green Apple Purple: Grape  Here in the UK we have it as: Red: Strawberry Orange: Orange Yellow: Lemon Green: Lime Purple: Blackcurrant  Food laws in the UK are obscenely strict and as a result all colourings and flavours have to be natural if they want to avoid heavy taxing.

Nah man, that's not how you make skittles. You got most of it right, but the coating process isn't right. You use a tumbler, get some white sugar syrup, tumble, and then add powdered sugar. Repeat this step after 20 mins or so with each colored batch. Think of it like a law breaker layer. That's how they do it on an industrial scale.

Â @TheOldAmishManÂ  No. Black Currant is a berry where licorice is a root. Radically different flavors. Black currants are not native to North America and they serve as a disease vector for White Pine Blister which can be devastating to the timber industry so their cultivation is largely prohibited. The flavor is not banned, it just isn't widely available due to lack of cultivation.

Our purple Skittles are grape because blackcurrants carry a powder mold that is deadly to native redwoods, and thus are banned from cultivation in the US. Hence, blackcurrant flavor isn't a thing here outside of UK treats in import shops.

Imagin one afternoon in your kindergarten class a friend brings Skittles for snack time. The teacher seeing he only brought one bag decides to give everyone in the class two Skittles apiece, and you so happen to be the lucky child that gets one green skittle and one yellow skittle. Thus your love for Skittles begins. You go home to your mother and ask her to buy you a bag just so you can experience the joy of the lemon-lime heaven you tasted just mere hours ago. Now flash forward fifteen years, fifteen years of life filled with its ups and downs and one of the very few joys you get in life is mixing your two favorite flavors together to achieve natural bliss amongst shattering reality. Lemon-Lime. Now your mother tells you to go to the local store for her afternoon fountain drink, which is ninety-nine cents at the time, and upon completing said purchase you find that you have enough money for your favorite treat. You go reach for a bag, expecting to find the sweet flavors of eternal happiness, only to see they changed the flavor to green apple. Upon trying this blasphemous flavor you realize that this skittle single handedly destroyed your childhood and all fond memories that go with it. Suddenly your once perfect life is marred with utter corruption, you start to fall apart, you think for the first time ever that maybe this isn't you candy anymore, that this candy ( like all the other things in your life ) has abandoned you to the wayside merely just to try a new flavor; not realizing they were committing the greatest sin since eve bit the forbbiden fruit. You life, reality, and very essence are now shattered. All this, because someone decided green apple was better than lime.

Konpeito (Japanese sugar candy spiked balls) are literally compressed sugar with colouring. You can't call the Smarties sold in the UK 'compressed' sugar in any way, because the shells AREN'T compressed onto the chocolate! that would be impractical to do because they make at least a few thousand per batch. So real skittles all taste pretty much the same. That is, the filling isn't flavored differently with extracts or additives. The different "flavors" come from scents that are part of the hard sugar shell. You smell lemon, you see yellow, your brain tells you you're going to taste lemon. A little bit of citric acid is pretty much all they do flavor wise to reinforce that. So the flavors come more from your anticipation of flavor than the candy itself.

How i would have done it, leave the centers unflavored. once those are shaped and formed freeze or chill them, put in rock tumbler. make a hard crack sugar syrup and add coloring and flavoring to the syrups and put in a squirt bottle and gently squirt into the tumbler until the hard shells have formed. add a food grade wax if you want the shiny factor. Process is called panning and its how candymakers have done hard candy coatings for at least a hundred years. much less of a headache. would like to see you come back to this and try doing something along these lines and see if its less frustrating.
Because the information is unknown

Dunno if you're serious but... a candy coat is basically dead easy. You bring a loose candy syrup (equal parts water and sugar) to the hard crack stage, flavor it if needed, color if desired. Put the candies you want to coat into a big ol huge bowl and roll around to coat them.  Fun cooking tip, if you're a masochist this would be how you make layered jawbreakers in a home kitchen. Start with a hard candy, then just coat it in layers of candy coating of different colors. But if you do this and you're not a manufacturing company with industrial drums... yeah you crazy.

+Jason Harrison:  Thank you, I was unfamiliar with the Mallen Streak.  Yeah, looks like that's what it is.  Apparently it can affect different areas of hair, but when it affects hair right above the forehead, as with these ladies, it's popularly known as "white forelock". Maybe it really is more about learning about the process. Because it will help you figuring out something similiar in the future.

I think it's also about breaking the illusion that people are born brilliant at things, like she didn't wake up that day, knowing exactly how to do this, she struggled and worked for over a week to get it right. I certainly fail at basically everything the first time, so it's comforting to see even an expert/professional has to work at something sometimes

Of course, i just took that for granted, just shows that i miss stuff too. As i also know that what you are describing is a common problem made more into common problem by social media. As everyone just posts amazing/good stuff. So if you don't take care you mare led into the trap of believing something along the lines: "Those people never have it hard, my life is so miserable!" I isolated myself from that part of the internet so i sometimes forget about. That's filter bubble. As an introvert i don't think it especially appealing posting about my own achievements as they are "boring past stuff" just like other peoples achievements. How to get there, now that's a completely different matter. That's stuff that impacts the future, or more specific: things i can do. That's why i am lurking in random comments sections like this one.

Exactly! That's why I love the movie Iron Man so much. Even though Tony was indeed kind of born a genius, he still makes mistakes and takes his time to come up with ideas, figure stuff out, sometimes start from scratch. The whole "inventing the Mark 2 suit" sequence is such a pleasure to watch for this exact reason.  This video is excellent.

Your shell coating is probably nothing more than hard candy: sugar, water & acid.

The shell coating is normally applied with something called a shell molding machine. It''s basically a drum with a lid that can seal and withstand (or release) the pressure difference created when the initially hot constituents cool down to room temperature.

The [citric] acid inverts sugar with heat. The amino acids (from protein) in the butter and the sugar undergo the Maillard reaction in heat which produces distinct flavor compounds that may be at odds with what you are trying to produce (that, and cost, is why they use PKO [1]), if you want to use butter then clarify it first, you can also use [neutral] leaf lard.   1. I get what he means though. (Compressed sugar) Skittles have like a grittiness inside. I don't think it's straight up taffy and that the fat is the problem. It's more like sugar that was probably melted, tempered or chemically altered, and then left to crystalize in a mold.   I can tell you that the coloring on candy like that is done in a tumbler (probably so is the shell itself). Liquid and powdered coloring will be added and they'll be tumbled, sometimes for hours or even days!, and then edible wax will be added and they'll be tumbled some more.  Also: You are a HORRIBLE Pastry chef if you don't understand these things.

You couldn't do grape? You said you tried freeze dried grapes. Maybe regular raisins? Grape skins maybe? I feel the grape flavor is more so in the skin where their odd type of bitterness also comes from. Maybe use their meat to tame it if it's too strong. Grape meat alone tastes more like sweetened gelatin so using the meat as the base for the flavor won't create a noticeable grape flavor. Grapes are just one of those fruits that are more difficult to translate into natural candy flavor.

Raisins and grapes taste completely different.

It was just a suggestion as raisins are just dried grapes anyway. They taste different because raisins don't have the water from the grape anymore. Saying a raisin tastes different from the original grape is a nonsequitur in this case because as I said, it's the grape skin that, for me, creates the iconic bitterness of the grape. The grape meat alone doesn't have a particularly unique fruit flavor. Eat any dried fruit & you can say it doesn't taste the same in every case (duh). The whole point of my suggestion was to get that iconic grape flavor. You didn't really add a whole lot to the idea of creating a natural grape flavor for candy.

Yes! It's super easy, but it's usually much more pastel. I actually got the recipe for food coloring inside one of my mail-order meal services.  Here's the one for orange, which makes about half a cup:  Roughly chop 3 carrots. In small saucepan over medium high heat, combine chopped veggie with 1 cup water. Bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer, and simmer until the water is the desired shade of orange (approx 25 - 30 min). Let cool. Using a blender, puree everything and pour through a strainer. Transfer to a clean jar. Use within 2 weeks. Or freeze in ice cube tray for longer storage.  I'm a terrible cook, haha. Hence why I tried out a meal delivery service. And this is super super easy to me!

There were so many unnecessary steps in this, though I suppose some of it can't be avoided in a home style kitchen. Great job at the end, and the little measuring spoon tongs to shape them worked out very nicely. But skittles are made as a toffee base and poured into moulds, there is no pulling of sugar in the original recipe. The coating is probably applied in a drum that is constantly turning, same for the colour, and then a final turn with the wax to polish the shells. At least that's now the coating is applied to candy coated chocolates. Also so sad about the lack of grape, but grape is my favourite and I can't imagine that it can be improved upon. The artificialness of that one is why it works for me.

If I give you mashed potatoes with just salt & butter, then another pile of mashed potatoes from the same batch where I've blended in lots of garlic, they look nearly identical but definitely do not taste the same. There will be similarities, sure, but one of them is now noticeably garlicky. Not in the US. That wouldn't happen because farming it was banned for a while in the early 20th Century due to its ability to spread a disease that affected pine trees and threatened our logging industry. Therefore, the flavor never became well-known here, so it wouldn't be a popular flavor for a mass-market candy like Skittles. That could change in the future now that the ban has been lifted more or less nationwide and blackcurrant is gaining popularity, but it's nowhere near as popular as it is in the UK.

I really love these videos, but - unpopular opinion here - I get annoyed that Brad is in so many of them. It makes sense in this video because everyone gets involved and he seems to especially be Claire's friend. He's a fun guy and I love his videos. But the rest of time - in videos featuring other people - it feels like a self insert that distracts viewers from the main person, and so many of the comments end up being about Brad. I'm not sure if he understands that by being present, he's stealing limelight from other people because of his sort of fandom. Maybe the original people are fine with sharing the limelight, but I feel like his popularity drowns out the appreciation for the person who made the video in the first place. They work so hard, only for tons of comments to talk about the 5 seconds Brad was in the video. So, nothing against him, but I wish Brad was in less of them, so more people can focus on and appreciate the original creator.

I watched an episode of "How It's Made" where they showed how some candies with candy shell and coloring were coated and colored.  They are put together into a giant tumbler that looks like a big dryer.  As the candies are continuously tumbled so as not to stick to each other, they pour in some ladles of the coating liquid.  The tumbler ensures they are evenly coated with it.  Then they pour in some ladles of coloring liquid, and the tumbler ensures they are evenly colored.  That's all there is to that.

Blackcurrant is not really much of a thing in the United States because the actual crop itself is heavily restricted.  That's because the blackcurrant is susceptible to several different pests and diseases and historically, attempts to introduce the blackcurrant crop in the United States has resulted in damage to forests due to a fungus called "white pine blister rust", which affects other types of trees.   Green Skittles were originally lime, but were changed to green apple around 2013.  Several confectioneries made in the United States have made a transition from lime to green apple, to include Skittles, Sweet Tarts, Runts, and Lifesavers, because market research suggested in the 2000s and 2010s that green apple would be a more popular flavor than lime.

Oliver del Toro It's a trick taken from Journalism, these kinds of videos are intended to go viral and be shared, proper nouns don't add to new people's desire to click. Honestly when I see names, I think "Okay, I don't know this person, so there's probably some inside jokes and what not I wouldn't get", but videos like this honestly are more clickable and I can say I wouldn't have clicked if her name was in it. You see a clean and professional title that perfectly delivers the video's purpose and you just click. Same thing applies to a pair of videos from a male pastry chef testing boxed cakes and girl scout cookies, they both say "Pastry chef reviews blah blah".
King Barney that's a great insight into the world of viral videos. Thanks mate
I see your point, and it makes sense. Perhaps if Bon Appetit didn't use Brad's name in the title of all of his videos, I wouldn't have been as bothered.

In short, claire's show is more driven by the knowledge she brings, while clearly brad's show is about his personality and the editing jokes etc. I don't thinks it is because of any form of sexism or discrimination.
